newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Iraq, Kuwait and allies discuss Gulf War missing.
newsitem.headline: Iraq, Kuwait and allies discuss Gulf War missing.

text.p: Iraq, Kuwait and some of Kuwait's allies on Wednesday held their first meeting since the latest Iraq crisis to discuss the fate of some 600 people missing since the 1990-91 Gulf crisis.
"The meeting started under the auspices of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)," U.N. spokesman Saleem Fahmawi told Reuters by telephone.
He said officials from Iraq, Kuwait, the United States, France, Britain and Saudi Arabia took part.

A standoff between Washington and Baghdad began on August 31 when Iraqi troops got involved in Kurdish factional fighting in northern Iraq -- closed to Baghdad for the last five years. The United States retaliated by firing missiles at Iraqi targets and ordering a military buildup.

Wednesday's talks in a technical committee, one in a series of ICRC-arranged meetings, convened on the Kuwaiti side of the border with Iraq at a camp of the United Nations Iraq-Kuwait Observer Mission (UNIKOM). UNIKOM provides the meeting place as a neutral party.
Accounting for the missing, who include Kuwaitis and other nationals, is among U.N. demands to ease sanctions imposed against Iraq since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.

An official Iraqi newspaper said on Sunday an Iraqi human rights body had set up a committee to trace missing Kuwaitis. Iraq has said it freed all those captured during the crisis but promised to continue to look into the issue.
